{"version":3,"steps":[{"id":"fbfc5f18f2b2-3bd8293db25e8851-7748","type":"prompt","dataType":"["Diabetes-info","Symptoms & Causes","Managing Diabetes","Risk Factors","Preventions","Diabetes Eating & Physical","Tests & Diagnosis","Insulin & Medicine Treatments","Any consultant"]","designer":{"xLocation":811,"yLocation":0,"listStyle":3,"next":"01f314e5ec64-58383e4eed20014a-a640"},"text":"Wecome to Healthcare......","variable":"help","submitTitle":"Submit","stringId":"stringId_07c537a9482880cb","choiceType":"choice","label":"Greet"},{"id":"01f314e5ec64-58383e4eed20014a-a640","type":"branch","condition":"scenario.help.index===0;","designer":{"xLocation":832,"yLocation":47,"next":"4fdf2d00cc97-b1acb1cd9febbe99-f0a7"},"targetStepId":"22d7fd0b8911-867740936040e6b1-33bc","label":"diabetes"},{"id":"4fdf2d00cc97-b1acb1cd9febbe99-f0a7","type":"branch","condition":"scenario.help.index===1;","designer":{"xLocation":740,"yLocation":60,"next":"5f815521b1c8-611ff94ab84abe84-ddef"},"targetStepId":"6add8140d945-2dd3cb95539e39c2-0d3b","label":"symptoms"},{"id":"5f815521b1c8-611ff94ab84abe84-ddef","type":"branch","condition":"scenario.help.index===2;","designer":{"xLocation":640,"yLocation":60,"next":"9a56f7e39ad1-4a60a322aa68f813-e436"},"label":"managing_diabetes","targetStepId":"042d35766f56-c3b06e3d9e0e0874-3e31"},{"id":"042d35766f56-c3b06e3d9e0e0874-3e31","type":"prompt","dataType":"["What happens if my blood glucose level becomes too low?","What happens if my blood glucose level becomes too high?","more info"]","designer":{"xLocation":594,"yLocation":140,"listStyle":3,"next":"0882c01176f3-cc158dfcd151e487-fa0e"},"text":"loading managing................
Working toward your ABC goals can help lower your chances of having a heart attack, stroke, or other diabetes problems.
1.A for the A1C test
The A1C test shows your average blood glucose level over the past 3 months. The A1C goal for many people with diabetes is below 7 percent. Ask your health care team what your goal should be.

2.B for Blood pressure
The blood pressure goal for most people with diabetes is below 140/90 mm Hg. Ask what your goal should be.

3.C for Cholesterol
You have two kinds of cholesterol in your blood: LDL and HDL. LDL or “bad” cholesterol can build up and clog your blood vessels. Too much bad cholesterol can cause a heart attack or stroke. HDL or “good” cholesterol helps remove the “bad” cholesterol from your blood vessels.

4.S for Stop smoking
Not smoking is especially important for people with diabetes because both smoking and diabetes narrow blood vessels. 
Keeping your A1C, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels close to your goals and stopping smoking may help prevent the long-term harmful effects of diabetes. These health problems include heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, nerve damage, and eye disease.

b)Follow your diabetes meal plan
Choose fruits and vegetables, beans, whole grains, chicken or turkey without the skin, fish, lean meats, and nonfat or low-fat milk and cheese. Drink water instead of sugar-sweetened beverages. Choose foods that are lower in calories, saturated fat, trans fat, sugar, and salt. Learn more about eating, diet, and nutrition with diabetes.

c)Make physical activity part of your daily routine
Set a goal to be more physically active. Try to work up to 30 minutes or more of physical activity on most days of the week.
Brisk walking and swimming are good ways to move more. If you are not active now, ask your health care team about the types and amounts of physical activity that are right for you. Learn more about being physically active with diabetes.

recommended targets for blood glucose levels?
Many people with diabetes aim to keep their blood glucose at these normal levels:

Before a meal: 80 to 130 mg/dL
About 2 hours after a meal starts: less than 180 mg/dL

Note:-IF you want to gocto the MENU TYPE -(start over)","variable":"eat","submitTitle":"Submit","stringId":"stringId_20c1d3fa60ba6e65","label":"eating"},{"id":"67852ab0d3df-ea667a408b70163a-4f83","type":"branch","condition":"scenario.help.index===6;","designer":{"xLocation":166,"yLocation":60,"next":"364cdc62442e-4aeac610a38bee4e-f437"},"targetStepId":"348c63682b4e-9b2ff407db24114a-4d02","label":"test"},{"id":"348c63682b4e-9b2ff407db24114a-4d02","type":"prompt","dataType":"string","designer":{"xLocation":191,"yLocation":140},"text":"Loading test and dignosis.............

Diabetes is diagnosed and managed by checking your glucose level in a blood test.

1.Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) test
The FPG blood test measures your blood glucose level at a single point in time. For the most reliable results, it is best to have this test in the morning, after you fast for at least 8 hours. Fasting means having nothing to eat or drink except sips of water.

2.A1c test
This test, also called HbA1C or glycated hemoglobin test, provides your average blood glucose level over the past two to three months. This test measures the amount of glucose attached to hemoglobin, the protein in your red blood cells that carries oxygen.

3.Oral glucose tolerance test
In this test, blood glucose level is first measured after an overnight fast. Then you drink a sugary drink. Your blood glucose level is then checked at hours one, two and three.

For further info https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/tests-diagnosis


Note:-IF you want to gocto the MENU TYPE -(start over)","variable":"test","submitTitle":"Submit","label":"test","stringId":"stringId_c6cc3ccad4452298"},{"id":"364cdc62442e-4aeac610a38bee4e-f437","type":"branch","condition":"scenario.help.index===7;","designer":{"xLocation":80,"yLocation":66,"next":"ebd12180a110-8061a4186cc7112e-e045"},"label":"medicine","targetStepId":"5037985a8cb7-37f12ff215042b9d-5719"},{"id":"5037985a8cb7-37f12ff215042b9d-5719","type":"prompt","dataType":"string","designer":{"xLocation":111,"yLocation":140},"text":"Loading..........

","label":"consultant","stringId":"stringId_41d017327eb23657"},{"id":"22d7fd0b8911-867740936040e6b1-33bc","type":"prompt","dataType":"string","designer":{"xLocation":971,"yLocation":80},"text":"Loading Diabetes-info..............


Diabetes is a disease that occurs when your blood glucose, also called blood sugar, is too high.Blood glucose is your main source of energy and comes from the food you eat. Insulin, a hormone made by the pancreas, helps glucose from food get into your cells to be used for energy. Sometimes your body doesn’t make enough—or any—insulin or doesn’t use insulin well. Glucose then stays in your blood and doesn’t reach your cells.

Over time, having too much glucose in your blood can cause health problems. Although diabetes has no cure, you can take steps to manage your diabetes and stay healthy.
There are different types of diabetes i.e TYPE 1 and TYPE 2 and gestational diabetes.
TyPE 1:-If you have type 1 diabetes, your body does not make insulin.
a)Your immune system attacks and destroys the cells in your pancreas that make insulin.
b)Type 1 diabetes is usually diagnosed in children and young adults, although it can appear at any age.
c)People with type 1 diabetes need to take insulin every day to stay alive.

TYPE 2:-
a)If you have type 2 diabetes, your body does not make or use insulin well.
b)You can develop type 2 diabetes at any age, even during childhood. However, this type of diabetes occurs most often in middle-aged and older people. Type 2 is the most common type of diabetes.


Note:-IF you want to gocto the MENU TYPE -(start over)","variable":"diabetes_info","submitTitle":"Submit","label":"Diabetes","stringId":"stringId_03ab27c0a28f3d3f"},{"id":"6add8140d945-2dd3cb95539e39c2-0d3b","type":"prompt","dataType":"["symptoms","causes of type 1","causes of type 2","What other factor cause diabetes"]","designer":{"xLocation":840,"yLocation":140,"listStyle":3,"next":"666814301004-6e6d62ae3cdd1939-1b4c"},"variable":"symptoms","submitTitle":"Submit","choiceType":"choice"},{"id":"666814301004-6e6d62ae3cdd1939-1b4c","type":"switch","designer":{"xLocation":900,"yLocation":174,"next":"a8d70db42b44-e0d64658b30006f6-9b0a"},"cases":[{"value":"symptoms","targetStepId":"c23472ba4869-85d9e0c3683cecbb-8cef"},{"value":"causes of type 1","targetStepId":"77e7e71c969d-c48d1540761f097b-64ee"},{"value":"causes of type 2","targetStepId":"64829c51d307-2d818a001cafd23e-97ef"},{"value":"What other factors cause Diabetes","targetStepId":"7ed7279616fd-d9644c56f5b9bb2c-e631"}],"condition":"${symptoms}.entity"},{"id":"c23472ba4869-85d9e0c3683cecbb-8cef","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":800,"yLocation":310},"text":"Symptoms include:- 

1.Increased thirst.
2.Weak, tired feeling.
3.Blurred vision.
4.Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet.
5.Slow-healing sores or cuts.
6.Unplanned weight loss.
7.Frequent urination.
8.Frequent unexplained infections.
9.Dry mouth

Other symptoms

In women: Dry and itchy skin, and frequent yeast infections or urinary tract infections.
In men: Decreased sex drive, erectile dysfunction, decreased muscle strength.

Many people with type 2 diabetes have no symptoms. Some people do not find out they have the disease until they have diabetes-related health problems, such as blurred vision or heart trouble.","stringId":"stringId_09ebafb5c2a5baf9"},{"id":"77e7e71c969d-c48d1540761f097b-64ee","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":920,"yLocation":427},"text":"Causes of TYPE1:-
Type 1 diabetes occurs when your immune system, the body’s system for fighting infection, attacks and destroys the insulin-producing beta cells of the pancreas.

For more info.....
https://www.diabetes.org/diabetes/type-1","stringId":"stringId_cf14139b0e606bb4"},{"id":"64829c51d307-2d818a001cafd23e-97ef","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":960,"yLocation":330},"text":"Type2:-Type 2 diabetes is the most common form of diabetes—and it means that your body doesn’t use insulin properly. Your pancreas can’t keep up and make enough insulin to overcome this resistance. Glucose levels rise in your bloodstream
Causes of TYPE 2:-

1.Overweight, obesity, and physical inactivity:-
Extra weight sometimes causes insulin resistance and is common in people with type 2 diabetes. The location of body fat also makes a difference. Extra belly fat is linked to insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and heart and blood vessel disease. 

2.Insulin resistance :-
Type 2 diabetes usually begins with insulin resistance, a condition in which muscle, liver, and fat cells do not use insulin well. As a result, your body needs more insulin to help glucose enter cells. At first, the pancreas makes more insulin to keep up with the added demand. Over time, the pancreas can’t make enough insulin, and blood glucose levels rise.

3.Genes and family history :-
As in type 1 diabetes, certain genes may make you more likely to develop type 2 diabetes. The disease tends to run in families and occurs more often in these racial/ethnic groups

for more information https://www.diabetes.org/diabetes/type-2","stringId":"stringId_04ea181df2d3ad1d"},{"id":"a8d70db42b44-e0d64658b30006f6-9b0a","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":1013,"yLocation":160},"text":"hey i am ","label":"factors","stringId":"stringId_fe09f59e6d980b68"},{"id":"7ed7279616fd-d9644c56f5b9bb2c-e631","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":917,"yLocation":272},"text":"What else can cause diabetes?

1.Genetic mutations
2.Hormonal diseases

for more information:-
https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/symptoms-causes","label":"other","stringId":"stringId_1fdc956bdc0b5fb4"},{"id":"0882c01176f3-cc158dfcd151e487-fa0e","type":"switch","designer":{"xLocation":680,"yLocation":151,"next":"0f1e21d649f3-cfaa82773972e8e0-a242"},"cases":[{"value":"What happens if my blood glucose level becomes too low?","targetStepId":"7c10b43a3a8a-f19e652a9d133f36-1284"},{"value":"What happens if my blood glucose level becomes too high?","targetStepId":"eb4535fff45d-785a1f270f6ac687-ffb8"},{"value":"More info","targetStepId":"bbee905a3dc5-8393208058f03350-8b29"}],"condition":"${manage_diabetes}.entity"},{"id":"0f1e21d649f3-cfaa82773972e8e0-a242","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":751,"yLocation":140},"text":"DEFAULT","stringId":"stringId_5b39c8b553c821e7"},{"id":"7c10b43a3a8a-f19e652a9d133f36-1284","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":614,"yLocation":308},"text":"Sometimes blood glucose levels drop below where they should be, which is called hypoglycemia. For most people with diabetes, the blood glucose level is too low when it is below 70 mg/dL.

Hypoglycemia can be life threatening and needs to be treated right away.","stringId":"stringId_b7f3516fd9ce6a99"},{"id":"eb4535fff45d-785a1f270f6ac687-ffb8","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":691,"yLocation":340},"text":"Symptoms that your blood glucose levels may be too high include

feeling thirsty
feeling tired or weak
headaches
urinating often
blurred vision
If you often have high blood glucose levels or symptoms of high blood glucose, talk with your health care team. ","stringId":"stringId_1464d49e09b450be"},{"id":"bbee905a3dc5-8393208058f03350-8b29","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":760,"yLocation":340},"text":"For more info....
https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/managing-diabetes","stringId":"stringId_ad827c653513931e"},{"id":"ada5e07fd14d-b2f4be8367b0149a-117f","type":"switch","designer":{"xLocation":460,"yLocation":206,"next":"a7c854abfbd3-e3f1481879c46e0a-9d11"},"cases":[{"value":"risk factor type1","targetStepId":"69496950903a-f84a50c96afdeae9-1536"},{"value":"risk factor type 2","targetStepId":"b4de93e8a2d3-5f087d33e647c8a2-7c1f"}],"condition":"${risk}.entity","label":"risk"},{"id":"a7c854abfbd3-e3f1481879c46e0a-9d11","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":580,"yLocation":200},"text":"Default","stringId":"stringId_7a1920d61156abc0"},{"id":"69496950903a-f84a50c96afdeae9-1536","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":400,"yLocation":352},"text":"Risk factor TYPE 1:-
Having a family history (parent or sibling) of Type 1 diabetes.
Injury to the pancreas (such as by infection, tumor, surgery or accident).
Presence of autoantibodies (antibodies that mistakenly attack your own body’s tissues or organs).
Physical stress (such as surgery or illness).
Exposure to illnesses caused by viruses.","stringId":"stringId_66d329b064c5a62a"},{"id":"b4de93e8a2d3-5f087d33e647c8a2-7c1f","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":515,"yLocation":369},"text":"Risk factors TYPE 2:-
Family history (parent or sibling) of prediabetes or Type 2 diabetes.
Being African-American, Hispanic, Native American, Asian-American race or Pacific Islander.
Being overweight.
Having high blood pressure.
Having low HDL cholesterol (the “good” cholesterol) and high triglyceride level.
Being physically inactive.
Being age 45 or older.
Having gestational diabetes or giving birth to a baby weighing more than 9 pounds.
Having polycystic ovary syndrome.
Having a history of heart disease or stroke.
Being a smoker.

For further info:- https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/risk-factors-type-2-diabetes","stringId":"stringId_1de8311f2427e523"},{"id":"ea3609f878a8-bd80411fc1fdde7f-dabc","type":"switch","designer":{"xLocation":249,"yLocation":194},"cases":[{"value":"preventing type 2","targetStepId":"c3e34892ec73-c613c2da04cf1b06-d42d"},{"value":"prevention diabetes problem","targetStepId":"689a4d775329-699a30a63be4aa42-7ccf"}],"condition":"${prevention}.entity","label":"Prevention"},{"id":"c3e34892ec73-c613c2da04cf1b06-d42d","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":160,"yLocation":380},"text":"Diabetes can cause serious health problems, such as heart disease, stroke, and eye and foot problems. Prediabetes also can cause health problems. The good news is that type 2 diabetes can be delayed or even prevented.
You can help prevent or delay type 2 diabetes by losing a modest amount of weight by following a reduced-calorie eating plan and being physically active most days of the week. 

1.Lose weight and keep it off
2.Eat healthy foods most of the time.
3.Move more. Get at least 30 minutes of physical activity 5 days a week. Start slowly to build up to your goal. 
4.Choosing foods with less fat is another way to reduce calories.
5.Drink water instead of sweetened beverages.

Follow this link to ADD PLAN Schedule --> https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/preventing-type-2-diabetes/game-plan","stringId":"stringId_76760432562c7a2a","label":"preventing type 2"},{"id":"689a4d775329-699a30a63be4aa42-7ccf","type":"statement","designer":{"xLocation":348,"yLocation":460},"text":"Prevention from Diabetic Problems:-
Follow this page --> https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/preventing-problems/all-content","stringId":"stringId_0b83d8d4df128203","label":"prevention diabetes problem"}],"breaking":false,"interrupting":false,"returningMessage":"Welcome to HealthCare"}
